thread.title: LSL shirks Brexit fears to deliver stronger than expected profits

author: Jonathon Manning
title: LSL shirks Brexit fears to deliver stronger than expected profits
text:
LSL shirks Brexit fears to deliver stronger than expected profits The firm said improved house sales will improve its half-year results, which will be published in August Share Your Move lettings board (Image: Pic from Your Move media centre) Share Get business   Thank you for subscribing!   
LSL Property Services has told investors its half-year profit figures will be higher than expected, after previously warning that its financials would be hit by the Brexit vote. 
In the upbeat announcement LSL, which runs Your Move and Reeds Rains from its Newcastle-headquarters , said sales during the last three months had been strong across both its estate agent and surveying divisions. 
In the statement the firm said: “Trading for the first half of 2017 has been strong including a good performance in June. LSL therefore expects to report strong interim results on August 1 ahead of the board’s expectations and significantly ahead of the same period last year, with the estate agency division performing ahead of the board’s expectation and delivering strong growth in lettings and financial services income, and with a strong performance by the surveying division.” 
The firm added: “As a result, the board anticipates that full year 2017 group underlying operating profit will be materially ahead of its prior expectations, with a more equal weighting between the first and second half compared to prior years.” 
Last August the firm posted strong half-year results, in which its turnover grew by 8% to £151.4m, and pre-tax profits soared 35% to £8.4m. 
Initially LSL had said that the UK’s decision to leave the EU could impact its results but so far the business seems to have remained unscathed by Brexit. Read More Newcastle property giants LSL says profits likely to be hit after EU vote 
This morning’s quarterly trading update is more optimistic than previous statements. In April 2017 the firm said that house sales had dipped during the first quarter of the year. 
But rather than blaming the drop in sales on Brexit, LSL said its numbers looked weak compared to the first three months of 2016 when buyers surged to purchase houses in the run-up to a change in stamp duty regulations. 
LSL’s share price has soared following the announcement. Like us on Facebook
